trans-unit.source: Represents a link within a <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.LinkLabel"></xref> control.
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.LinkLabel.Link> class defines the properties of a link within a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.LinkLabel> control.

You can use these properties to provide data to the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.LinkLabel.LinkClicked> event of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.LinkLabel> control to perform tasks when the link is clicked in the control.

The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.LinkLabel.Link.LinkData%2A> property enables you to define information that the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.LinkLabel.LinkClicked> event can use to display a URL within Microsoft Internet Explorer or to open a file.

In addition to information related to the link, the properties of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.LinkLabel.Link> class also help define the text of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.LinkLabel.Link> and its display state.

The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.LinkLabel.Link.Start%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.LinkLabel.Link.Length%2A> properties define the location and length of text from the text of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.LinkLabel> control to display as a link.

The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.LinkLabel.Link.Enabled%2A> property allows you to display the link as a disabled link, and the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.LinkLabel.Link.Visited%2A> property can alert the user that they already visited the specified link in the current instance of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.LinkLabel>.
You can display multiple links in a single <xref:System.Windows.Forms.LinkLabel> control.
Each <xref:System.Windows.Forms.LinkLabel.Link> is added into the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.LinkLabel.LinkCollection> associated with the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.LinkLabel> control.
To obtain the collection of links defined in a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.LinkLabel> control, use the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.LinkLabel.Links%2A?displayProperty=fullName> property.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.LinkLabel.Link"></xref> class.

Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.LinkLabel.Link"></xref> class with the specified starting location and number of characters after the starting location within the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.LinkLabel"></xref>.
The zero-based starting location of the link area within the text of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.LinkLabel"></xref>.
The number of characters, after the starting character, to include in the link area.

Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.LinkLabel.Link"></xref> class with the specified starting location, number of characters after the starting location within the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.LinkLabel"></xref>, and the data associated with the link.
The zero-based starting location of the link area within the text of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.LinkLabel"></xref>.
The number of characters, after the starting character, to include in the link area.
The data associated with the link.
Gets or sets a text description of the link.
A <xref href="System.String"></xref> representing a text description of the link.
Gets or sets a value indicating whether the link is enabled.
You can use this property to display a link in a disabled state within the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.LinkLabel> control.
When a link is disabled, clicking on the link does not cause the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.LinkLabel> control to raise the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.LinkLabel.LinkClicked> event.
`true` if the link is enabled; otherwise, `false`.
Gets or sets the number of characters in the link text.

To specify text from the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.LinkLabel> to display as a link, set the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.LinkLabel.Link.Start%2A> property to the location in the text to start creating the link.

After the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.LinkLabel.Link.Start%2A> property is set, set the value of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.LinkLabel.Link.Length%2A> property to the number of characters, including the character position specified in the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.LinkLabel.Link.Start%2A> property, that you want to make the link text.

For example, if you want to make the first word of the text "The quick brown fox" a link, you set the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.LinkLabel.Link.Start%2A> property to zero (0) and the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.LinkLabel.Link.Length%2A> property to three (3).
The number of characters, including spaces, in the link text.
Gets or sets the data associated with the link.
You can use this property to supply information related to the link.

The information provided by this property can be used within the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.LinkLabel.LinkClicked> event of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.LinkLabel> to provide information about the link that can be used to process the link being clicked.
For example, you can specify the URL to display in Internet Explorer when the link is clicked as the value of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.LinkLabel.Link.LinkData%2A> property.
You can also use the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.LinkLabel.Link.LinkData%2A> property to identify a dialog to display when the user clicks on the link.
An <xref href="System.Object"></xref> representing the data associated with the link.
Gets or sets the name of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.LinkLabel.Link"></xref>.
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.LinkLabel.Link.Name%2A> property is useful for indexing by key.
A <xref href="System.String"></xref> representing the name of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.LinkLabel.Link"></xref>.
The default value is the empty string ("").
Gets or sets the starting location of the link within the text of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.LinkLabel"></xref>.

To specify text from the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.LinkLabel> to display as a link, set the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.LinkLabel.Link.Start%2A> property to the location in the text to start creating the link.

After the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.LinkLabel.Link.Start%2A> property is set, set the value of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.LinkLabel.Link.Length%2A> property to the number of characters, including the character position specified in the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.LinkLabel.Link.Start%2A> property, that you want to make the link text.

For example, if you want to make the first word of the text "The quick brown fox" a link, you set the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.LinkLabel.Link.Start%2A> property to zero (0) and the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.LinkLabel.Link.Length%2A> property to three (3).
The location within the text of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.LinkLabel"></xref> control where the link starts.
Gets or sets the object that contains data about the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.LinkLabel.Link"></xref>.
An <xref href="System.Object"></xref> that contains data about the control.
The default is `null`.
Gets or sets a value indicating whether the user has visited the link.
A <xref:System.Windows.Forms.LinkLabel> control does not automatically denote that a link is a visited link.

To display the link as a visited link, you can set the value of this property to `true` in an event handler for the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.LinkLabel.LinkClicked> event of a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.LinkLabel>.
A visited link is displayed using the color specified in the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.LinkLabel.VisitedLinkColor%2A> property of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.LinkLabel> control.
Once the form containing the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.LinkLabel> control is closed, the all display state associated with the link is deleted.
In order to retain the display state of the link, you need to store the display state of the link in a registry setting associated with your application.

If you have only one link specified in a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.LinkLabel> control, you can use the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.LinkLabel.LinkVisited%2A> property of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.LinkLabel> to specify the link as visited.
You can also use the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.LinkLabel.LinkVisited%2A> property if you have multiple links defined, but the setting only applies to the first link defined in the control.
`true` if the link has been visited; otherwise, `false`.
